Chapter.Heading: Unions of Residue Classes with Fixed Representatives
Chapter.Section:
About unions of residue classes with fixed representatives
In this chapter we introduce a different kind of unions of residue classes, namely those of residue classes which are endowed with a distinguished (fixed) representative.
These unions of residue classes behave different than the ordinary residue class unions which we have described in the previous chapter:
-
In most situations they behave like lists of single residue classes with fixed representatives rather than like sets of ring elements. There are exceptions from this behaviour, e.g. w.r.t. forming differences, in order to ensure \rho-additivity (\rightarrow ).
-
They can be viewed as multisets of ring elements -- the residue classes in such a union are not necessarily disjoint, and not even necessarily distinct.
Unions of residue classes with fixed representatives play an important role in computations with residue class-wise affine mappings, and thus are needed by the &RCWA; package.
Throughout this chapter, the argument R denotes the ring whose residue classes we are dealing with, and the arguments U, U1 and U2 denote unions of residue classes of R with fixed representatives.
Some of the functionality described in this chapter makes only sense if R is the ring of integers -- in particular this holds for everything concerning the invariant \rho.

gap> cl1 in U; false gap> cl2 in U; true
the sorted list of the residue classes in U.
gap> AsListOfClasses(U); [ [1/2], [4/7] ]
Checks whether U2 is a subset of U1, i.e. that if a residue class [r/m] is contained k_1-fold in U1 and k_2-fold in U2, we always have k_1 \geq k_2.
gap> IsSubset(U,cl1); false gap> IsSubset(U,cl2); true
the natural density of U as a multiset (elements with multiplicity k count k-fold).
gap> Density(U); 9/14 gap> 1/2+1/7; 9/14
the union of U1 and U2.
We have Rho(Union(U1,U2)) = Rho(U1) + Rho(U2). (\rightarrow ).
gap> Union(U,cl1); [1/2] U [2/3] U [4/7]
the intersection of U1 and U2.
The multiplicity of any residue class in the intersection is the minimum of its multiplicities in the arguments.
gap> Intersection(cl1,cl2); Empty union of residue classes of Z with fixed representatives gap> Intersection(List([cl1,cl2],AsOrdinaryUnionOfResidueClasses)); The residue class 5(6) of Z gap> Intersection(cl2,U); [1/2]
the difference of U1 and U2.
We have Rho(Difference(U1,U2)) = Rho(U1) - Rho(U2). (\rightarrow ). This is ensured by setting the difference of the empty residue class union with fixed representatives and some residue class [r/m] equal to [(m-r)/m].
gap> Difference(U,cl1); [1/2] U [1/3] U [4/7] gap> Difference(U,cl2); [4/7]
Throughout the rest of this section we regard U as a multiset of ring elements. For sake of simplicity, we abbreviate the multiset of ring elements endowed with the structure of a union of residue classes with fixed representatives by the multiset.
the multiset of sums u + x, u \in U.
gap> cl1 + 1; [3/3] gap> U+23; [24/2] U [27/7]
the multiset of differences u - x, u \in U resp. the set of differences x - u, u \in U resp. the set of the additive inverses of the elements of U.
gap> cl2 - 1; [0/2] gap> U - 17; [-16/2] U [-13/7]
the multiset of products x \cdot u, u \in U.
Scalar multiplication leaves \rho invariant (\rightarrow ).
gap> 3*cl1; [6/9] gap> 7*U; [7/14] U [28/49]
the multiset of quotients u/x, u \in U.
Scalar division leaves \rho invariant (\rightarrow ). If not all elements of all residue classes in U are divisible by x, the method gives up.
gap> (2*cl1+2)/3; [2/2]

ManSection.Description:
We define the representative stabilizing refinement of a residue class [r/m] of \Z with fixed representative into k parts by [r/km] \cup [(r+m)/km] \cup \dots \cup [(r+(k-1)m)/km], and extend this definition in a natural way to unions of residue classes.
The method tries to perform a simplification of U by joining appropriate residue classes if the argument k is zero.
In any case the value of Rho(U) is invariant under this operation (\rightarrow ).
gap> cl := ResidueClassUnionWithFixedReps(Integers,[[2,1]]); [1/2] gap> S := RepresentativeStabilizingRefinement(cl,3); [1/6] U [3/6] U [5/6] gap> cls := AsListOfClasses(S); [ [1/6], [3/6], [5/6] ] gap> cls := List([1..3],i->RepresentativeStabilizingRefinement(cls[i],i+1)); [ [1/12] U [7/12], [3/18] U [9/18] U [15/18], [5/24] U [11/24] U [17/24] U [23/24] ] gap> S := Union(cls); <union of 9 residue classes of Z with fixed representatives> gap> RepresentativeStabilizingRefinement(S,0); [1/2]

Chapter.Section:
The categories of unions of residue classes with fixed representatives
The names of the categories of unions of residue classes with fixed representatives can be derived from the names of those of the ordinary unions of residue classes given in Section by appending WithFixedRepresentatives.
